Precise measurement of hadronic τ -decays
with an η meson
>Belle Collaboration
K. Inami s , T. Ohshima s , H. Kaji s , I. Adachi f , H. Aihara ak ,

ah University of Sydney, Sydney, NSW, Australia
ai Toho University, Funabashi, Japan
aj Tohoku Gakuin University, Tagajo, Japan
ak Department of Physics, University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
aℓ Tokyo Metropolitan University, Tokyo, Japan
am Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Tokyo, Japan
an IPNAS, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA,
USA
ao Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract
We have studied hadronic τ decay modes involving an η meson using 490 fb −1
of data collected with the Belle detector at the KEKB asymmetric-energy e + e −
collider. The following branching fractions have been measured: B(τ − → K − ην τ ) =
(1.58 ± 0.05 ± 0.09) × 10 −4 , B(τ − → K − π 0 ην τ ) = (4.6 ± 1.1 ± 0.4) × 10 −5 , B(τ − →
π − π 0 ην τ ) = (1.35±0.03±0.07)×10 −3 , B(τ − → π − K 0
S ην τ ) = (4.4±0.7±0.2)×10 −5 ,
and B(τ − → K * − ην τ ) = (1.34 ± 0.12 ± 0.09) × 10 −4 . These results are substantially
more precise than previous measurements. The new measurements are compared
with theoretical calculations based on the CVC hypothesis or the chiral perturbation
theory. We also set upper limits on branching fractions for τ decays into K − K 0
S ην τ ,
π − K 0
S π 0 ην τ , K − ηην τ , π − ηην τ and non-resonant K − π 0 ην τ final states.
text.body:
1 Introduction
Hadronic decays of the τ lepton are very important for studying QCD phe-
nomena at a low-energy scale. Various decay modes including an η-meson
represent a wide class of such decays, which are still poorly studied. One of
the important tasks in this field is to test effective chiral theories [1,2,3,4]. The
τ decay amplitudes in these theories are based on an effective Lagrangian of
pseudoscalar, vector and axial-vector mesons with U(3) L × U(3) R symmetry.
On the other hand, for some decays the branching fractions as well as spec-
tral functions of the final states can be predicted using the vector dominance
model (VDM). Another important issue is testing the relations between the
cross section of e + e − → π + π − η and the spectral function in τ − → π − π 0 ην τ
decay predicted by conservation of vector current (CVC) and isospin sym-
metry [5]. For all of the above tasks, precise measurements of the branching
fractions as well as detailed studies of the final-state invariant mass distribu-
tions are highly desirable.

Three τ -decay modes involving η mesons, τ − → K − ην τ
1 , τ − → K * (892) − ην τ ,
and τ − → π − π 0 ην τ , have been studied by CLEO [6,7,8] and ALEPH [9].
However, the experimental statistics were very limited. For example, CLEO
has the most precise measurements with 85 events in the τ − → K − ην τ mode,
125 events in the τ − → π − π 0 ην τ mode and 25 in the τ − → K * − ην τ mode.
The limited statistics of these measurements result in large uncertainties for
the branching fractions and do not allow study of the hadronic mass spectra.
We report a detailed study of the branching fractions for τ − → K − ην τ ,
K − π 0 ην τ , π − π 0 ην τ , as well as π − K 0
S ην τ decays. The K − π 0 invariant mass
in the K − π 0 ην τ decay and the π − K 0
S invariant mass in the π − K 0
S ην τ decay
are studied to evaluate the branching fraction of the τ − → K * (892) − ην τ decay.
In addition, some other final-state invariant mass distributions are presented
and discussed.
This study was performed at the KEKB asymmetric-energy e + e − collider [10]
with the Belle detector. The results are based on a 490 fb −1 data sample that
contains about 450 million τ -pairs, which is almost 100 times larger than in
any of the previous measurements.
The structure of this paper is as follows. Section 2 describes the Belle de-
tector. Event selection is explained in Section 3. The branching fractions are
determined in Section 4, where that of τ − → K * (892) − ην τ is evaluated from
analysis of the τ − → K − π 0 ην τ and π − K 0
S ην τ samples in Section 4.3. Finally,
some concluding remarks are given in Section 5.
2 Experimental apparatus and Monte-Carlo simulation
The Belle detector is a large-solid-angle magnetic spectrometer that consists
of a silicon vertex detector (SVD), a 50-layer central drift chamber (CDC), an
array of aerogel threshold Cherenkov counters (ACC), a barrel-like arrange-
ment of time-of-flight scintillation counters (TOF), and an electromagnetic
calorimeter (ECL) comprised of CsI(Tl) crystals located inside a supercon-
ducting solenoid coil that provides a 1.5 T magnetic field. An iron flux-return
located outside the coil is instrumented to detect K 0
L mesons and to identify
muons (KLM). The detector is described in detail elsewhere [11]. Two inner
detector configurations were used. A 2.0 cm radius beam pipe and a 3-layer
silicon vertex detector were used for the first sample of 140 fb −1 , while a 1.5
cm radius beam pipe, a 4-layer silicon detector and a small-cell inner drift
chamber were used to record the remaining 350 fb −1 [12].
text.note:
1 Unless specified otherwise, charge-conjugate decays are implied throughout the
paper.
text.body:
Particle identification (PID) of the charged tracks uses likelihood ratios, P x ,
for a charged particle of species x (x = µ, e, K, π or p). P x is defined as
P x = L x /Σ y L y (the sum runs over the relevant particle species), where L x
is a likelihood based on the energy deposit and shower shape in the ECL,
the momentum and dE/dX measured in the CDC, the particle range in the
KLM, the light yield in the ACC, and the particle's time-of-flight from the
TOF counter [13]. The efficiencies for kaon, muon and electron identification
are 77% for momenta of p > 0.3 GeV/c, 92% for p > 1.0 GeV/c and 94% for
p > 0.5 GeV/c, respectively.
The detection efficiency for each signal mode and the level of background (BG)
contribution are estimated from Monte Carlo (MC) simulations. To generate
signal events as well as τ -decay backgrounds, the KKMC program [14] is used.
For the decay modes not covered by KKMC, like τ − → K − ην τ , K * (892) − ην τ ,
. . ., the signal MC is produced assuming a pure phase-space distribution of the
hadronic system with a V −A weak interaction. The background from e + e − →
q q (q q continuum) is simulated using the EvtGen procedure [15]. The detector
response is simulated by a GEANT3 [16] based program. Throughout the
paper the efficiencies quoted include the branching ratios of the corresponding
η decays.
3 Event Selections
The signal events should have the following common features in the e + e − →
τ −
signal τ +
tag reaction:
τ −
signal → X − + η + n(≤ 1)γ + (missing),
τ +
tag → (µ/e) + + n(≤ 1)γ + (missing),
where X − denotes K − , K − π 0 , π − π 0 , π − K 0
S or K * (892) − systems. The π 0 ,
K 0
S and K * (892) − are reconstructed through π 0 → γγ, K 0
S → π + π − , and
K * (892) − → K 0
S π − , K − π 0 decays, respectively. The η meson is identified
through the η → γγ decay mode for all τ channels while the η → π + π − π 0
mode is added for the τ − → K − ην decay mode.
The signal events, therefore, comprise either two or four charged tracks with
zero net charge and two or four γ's. In order to take into account initial-state
radiation, we allow at most one extra γ on both the signal and tag sides. Each
charged track is required to have a transverse momentum p t > 0.1 GeV/c, and
a polar angle of −0.866 < cos θ < 0.956, where p t and θ are measured relative
to the direction opposite to that of the incident e + beam in the laboratory
frame. Each photon candidate should have an energy E γ > 0.05 GeV within
the same polar angle region as for the charged particles.

The tag-side τ tag is required to decay into leptons, i.e. τ + → ℓ + ν ℓ ντ (ℓ =
e/µ), which corresponds to a branching fraction of 35.2% [17]. The lepton
candidates are required to be well identified by requirements on the P e or P µ
PID parameters with p > 0.7 GeV/c.
The thrust axis (n thrust ) is defined to maximize V thrust = Σ i |p CM
i •n thrust |/Σ i |p CM
i |,
where p CM
i
denotes the momentum of each particle in the center-of-mass sys-
tem (CM), and the sum runs over all detected particles in an event. The
requirement V thrust > 0.8 is applied to remove q q events. An event is divided
into two hemispheres by the plane perpendicular to n thrust . The hemisphere
that includes τ signal with an η is referred to as the signal side, while the opposite
hemisphere, which includes τ tag , is defined as the tag side.
In order to remove non-τ pair backgrounds, such as the qq continuum, the
total energy in CM is required to be in the range 3.0 GeV < E CM
total < 10.0
GeV. In addition, the invariant masses of both the signal and the tag sides are
required to be smaller than the τ -mass: M sig , M tag < m τ (1.78 GeV/c 2 ). To
remove two-photon backgrounds, the missing momentum should correspond to
a particle crossing the fiducial region; we require that the missing momentum
satisfy −0.866 < cos θ(p miss ) < 0.956. After applying these requirements, the
q q background level is 3% of the signal yield. Background from two-photon
reactions is negligible.
To reconstruct an η, two γ's with E γ > 0.2 GeV are required in the barrel
region (−0.624 < cos θ < 0.833). In addition, we allow combinations with
at most one extra γ with 0.05 < E γ < 0.2 GeV in the endcap region on
the signal side to take into account initial-state radiation as well as beam-
induced BG clusters in the calorimeter. In order to reduce the number of
incorrect combinations with a γ from π 0 decay (denoted hereafter as γ π 0 ), the
η-candidate γ (γ η ) should not form a π 0 mass with any other γ, i.e., a π 0 -veto
is applied. The π 0 mass window is defined in this paper as 0.105 GeV/c 2 <
M γγ < 0.165 GeV/c 2 , which is a ±3σ range of the detector resolution.
3.1 τ − → K − ην τ decay
Candidate events for this decay mode must contain one charged track and at
least two γ's in the η → γγ case, or three charged tracks and two γ's in the
η → π + π − π 0 (π 0 → γγ) case.
A kaon is identified by the P K parameter with p > 0.3 GeV/c. In addition,
a low P e value is required to remove beam electrons from two-photon pro-
cesses; this requirement reduces two-photon BG to a negligible level. The
opening angle between the K − and η is required to satisfy the condition
cos θ(P CM
K ; P CM
η ) > 0.8, to reduce the combinatorial BG. In addition, the

Fig. 1. (a) M γγ and (b) M π + π − π 0 distributions for K − ην τ selection in η → γγ and
η → π − π + π 0 decays, respectively. Data are fit with a Crystal Ball function plus
a second-order polynomial for the BG. The best-fit result is indicated by the solid
curve with the BG shown by the dashed curve.
opening angle and energy of the two γ η 's should fulfill the following condi-
tions: 0.5 < cos θ(P CM
γ1 ; P CM
γ2 ) < 0.96 and |E CM
γ1 − E CM
γ2 |/|E CM
γ1 + E CM
γ2 | < 0.8,
respectively.
For η → π + π − π 0 reconstruction, the selection criteria are basically the same
as in the η → γγ case. Here η candidates should have two additional charged
tracks, and two of the γ's must form a π 0 instead of an η.
The γγ and π + π − π 0 invariant mass distributions around η mass are shown
in Figs.1 (a) and (b), respectively. The η peak is clearly seen in both cases.
The selection efficiencies (including the intermediate branching fractions of
B(η → γγ), B(η → π + π − π 0 ), and B(τ − → ℓ − ν τ νℓ )) are ǫ = 0.94% in the
η → γγ and ǫ = 0.16% in the η → π + π − π 0 case.

Fig. 2. Distribution of the likelihood ratio for (a) K − π 0 ην τ and (b) π − π 0 ην τ . Dots
are experimental data. The hatched and normal histograms indicate the signal and
BG MC distributions, respectively. The dashed line shows the threshold of this
selection.
3.2 τ − → K − π 0 ην τ and π − π 0 ην τ decays
For these decays, an η is reconstructed through the γγ mode only, so that the
signal event should contain one charged track and four γ's on the signal side.
All γ's, except for a possible extra γ, are required to be detected in the
barrel region of the calorimeter, and two of them should form a combina-
tion consistent the π 0 mass. The total momentum on the signal side is re-
quired to satisfy p CM
sig > 2.5 GeV/c. A condition on the opening angle be-
tween the missing momentum in the CM and the thrust axis is imposed:
cos θ(p CM
miss ; n sig
thrust ) < −0.6, to remove BG's with large missing momentum on
the signal side. Charged kaons and pions are selected by requiring large P K
and small P e in the K − π 0 ην τ mode, while small P K and small P e are selected
in the π − π 0 ην τ mode.
For further background rejection, we construct a likelihood using the following
seven variables: V thrust , momenta of the η and π 0 in the CM (p CM
η , p CM
π 0 ), the
missing-mass squared (M 2
miss ), the energy of the γ η 's in the CM (E CM
γη ), p CM
sig ,
and cos θ(p CM
K/π ; p CM
η ). The MC simulation is used to study the likelihood dis-
tributions of generic τ + τ − and the small residual q q BG (L BG ) as well as the
signal (L sig ). A likelihood ratio is defined as R = L sig /(L sig + L BG ). The R
distribution is shown in Figs. 2 (a) for K − π 0 ην τ and (b) for π − π 0 ην τ decay;
with the requirement R > 0.6, about half of the background is removed, while
93% and 90% of the signal samples are retained, respectively.
The resulting M γγ distributions are shown in Figs.3 (a) and (b) for the K − π 0 ην τ
and π − π 0 ην τ modes, respectively. The η peaks are clearly visible. The detec-
tion efficiencies are ǫ = 0.35% and 0.47% in the τ − → K − π 0 ην τ and π − π 0 ην τ

with a Crystal Ball function plus a second-order polynomial for the BG. The result
of the best fit is indicated by the solid curve with the BG shown by the dashed
curve.
decays, respectively.
3.3 π − K 0
S ην τ decay
On the signal side, three charged tracks and at least two γ's are required.
To suppress two-photon BG, the tracks should not be identified as electrons.
Without K/π ID the pion mass of m π ± = 0.13957 GeV/c 2 is assigned to all
three tracks on the signal side, two of the three tracks with opposite charges
are the K 0
S daughters, the invariant mass (M π + π − ) of which is required to be
within a K 0
S mass window (3σ), 0.4907 GeV/c 2 < M π + π − < 0.5047 GeV/c 2 . To
ensure that these tracks are K 0
S daughters, the distance from the interaction
point to the K 0
S decay vertex on the plane perpendicular to the beam axis
(r vertex ) is required to satisfy the condition: 0.5 cm < r vertex < 30 cm. To
avoid multiple candidates, the mass of the other possible combination must
not satisfy the K 0
S mass condition. Pairs of γ's with E γ > 0.3 GeV are used

to form η candidates. We require that the energy of an η candidate, E η , must
be greater than 1.2 GeV.
The resulting M γγ distribution is shown in Fig.5 (a). The detection efficiency
is ǫ = 0.32%, which includes the tag-side efficiency, B(η → γγ) and B(K 0
S →
π + π − ).
4 Branching Fractions
4.1 K − ην τ , K − π 0 ην τ and π − π 0 ην τ decays
4.1.1 Signal candidates
The η meson yields are obtained from fits to the γγ invariant mass distri-
butions shown in Figs.1 and 3. Fits are performed with a Crystal Ball (CB)
function [18] plus a second-order polynomial function to represent the η con-
tribution and combinatorial BG, respectively. All five parameters of the CB
function, as well as three others for BG are treated as free parameters in the
fit.
The results of the fit are shown by the solid curve in the corresponding fig-
ures. The best fits give η masses of M η = 0.5449 ± 0.0006, 0.5444 ± 0.0010
and 0.5443 ± 0.0004 GeV/c 2 for K − ην τ , K − π 0 ην τ , and π − π 0 ην τ decays, re-
spectively, in the η → γγ subsample, while M η = 0.5474 ± 0.0007 GeV/c 2 for
K − ην τ in the η → π + π − π 0 subsample. The corresponding mass resolutions are
σ Mη = 0.0110 ± 0.0006, 0.0107 ± 0.0015, 0.0116 ± 0.0003, and 0.0075 ± 0.0004
GeV/c 2 , respectively. These values of M η and σ Mη are in good agreement with
those obtained from the MC simulation, although the obtained masses are
shifted by 2 -3 σ from the η mass in Ref. [17], which is due to the incomplete
detector calibration. For instance, M MC
η
= 0.5442, 0.5450, 0.5464, and 0.5473
GeV/c 2 for a generated mass of m η = 0.54745 GeV/c 2 .
The η yields obtained from the fits are N η = 1, 387 ± 43, 270 ± 33, and
5, 959±105 events for the K − ην τ , K − π 0 ην τ , and π − π 0 ην τ modes, respectively,
in the η → γγ case, while N η = 241 ± 21 events for the K − ην τ decay in the
η → π + π − π 0 case. These yields include BG, attributed to other τ decays with
η meson(s), such as the τ − → π − π 0 π 0 ην τ and π − π + π − ην τ ; q q continuum with
η meson(s); cross-feeds among the signal modes.

4.1.2 Background
The possible backgrounds in the K − ην τ , K − π 0 ην τ and π − π 0 ην τ decay modes
include (a) feed-across from signal modes and (b) other processes such as
τ → π − π 0 π 0 ην τ , K − ηην τ , π − ηην τ , π − ην τ and q q. We first discuss the second
source.
BG from generic τ + τ − decays is evaluated using a MC simulation where the
value of B(τ − → π − π 0 π 0 ην τ ) is taken from Ref. [19]. This BG is negligible for
K − ην τ and K − π 0 ην τ decays, and is only 72 ± 20 events, which is smaller than
the statistical uncertainty in the η yield for the π − π 0 ην τ decay.
To examine the τ − → K − ηην τ and π − ηην τ contaminations, we analyze data
using selection criteria similar to those used for the K − π 0 ην τ and π − π 0 ην τ
modes. An additional η, instead of a π 0 , is reconstructed, and no selection on
the likelihood ratio is implemented. Requiring one photon pair to be in the η
mass region, 0.48GeV/c 2 < M (1)
γγ < 0.58 GeV/c 2 , which includes the largest
energy γ, the invariant mass distribution of the other η candidate, (M (2)
γγ ), is
shown in Figure 4. The evaluated η yields are 1.4 +2.6
−1.9 and 4.4 ± 6.8 events
in the K − ηην τ and π − ηην τ decays, respectively, with detection efficiencies of
ǫ = 0.19% and 0.22%, respectively. We then set the upper limits [20]
B(τ − → K − ηην τ ) < 3.0 × 10 −6
(1)
and
B(τ − → π − ηην τ ) < 7.4 × 10 −6
(2)
at the 90% confidence level (CL) including systematic uncertainties of 6.9%
and 7.1%, respectively. Since the cross feed probability for these modes with
extra η's is below 3%, their contamination is ignored.
The τ − → π − ην τ decay proceeds via a second-class current so that its branch-
ing fraction is expected to be small, as low as 10 −5 [3] or less. Since the
efficiency for detecting π − ην τ as signal is of the order of 10 −4 , the total con-
tamination is then ∼ 10 −9 or less so that this decay can be ignored.
BG from the q q continuum is examined using both MC and data in order to
take into account the η production uncertainty of the q q MC. A q q enriched
sample is produced with some variations of the signal selection criteria. We
require M tag > m τ , while the requirement M sig < m τ is not applied; the PID
requirement on the tag side is reversed. Other criteria are not changed. A
comparison between the resulting η yields of MC and the data resulted in
the following MC scale factors: 2.3 ± 0.7 for K − ην τ , 2.6 ± 0.5 for K − π 0 ην τ ,
and 2.9 ± 0.3 for π − π 0 ην τ . Therefore, we obtain rescaled q q contaminations of
39.7 ± 15.8 events in K − ην τ , 212 ± 29 events in π − π 0 ην τ and 27.0 ± 8.5 events

γγ for (a) the τ − → K − ηην τ sample and (b) the τ − → π − ηην τ sample. Data
are fit with a Crystal Ball function plus a second-order polynomial for the BG. The
result of the best fit is indicated by the solid curve with the BG shown by the dashed
curve.
in the K − π 0 ην τ decay. These BG's correspond to 2.8%, 10% and 3.6% of the
raw signal yields, N η , respectively.
The yields in the three candidate samples after the BG subtraction evaluated
above, N i , (i = K − ην, K − π 0 ην, π − π 0 ην) are used to evaluate the correspond-
ing branching fractions, B i . To take into account the cross-feeds between decay
channels, we solve the following system of linear equations:
N j = 2N τ τ
3
i=1
ǫ i
j B i
(j = 1, 2, 3),
(3)
where ǫ i
j is the efficiency for detecting mode j as mode i, which is estimated
by MC; N τ τ is the total number of τ -pairs produced. In the η → π + π − π 0 case,
B(τ − → K − ην τ ) is calculated using the relation N ′
1 = 2N τ τ
3
i=1 ǫ ′i
1 B i (the
prime indicates quantities for this η mode) with B 2 and B 3 obtained in the
η → γγ case. The statistical uncertainty in N ′
1 is ∼ 10%, while the cross-feed
contamination is ∼ 4%, and is thus insignificant.
The resulting branching fractions are B(τ − → K − ην τ ) = (1.57 ± 0.05) × 10 −4 ,
B(τ − → K − π 0 ην τ ) = (4.6 ± 1.1) × 10 −5 , and B(τ − → π − π 0 ην τ ) = (1.35 ±
0.03) × 10 −3 in the η → γγ case, and B(τ − → K − ην τ ) = (1.60 ± 0.15) × 10 −4
in the η → π + π − π 0 case.
4.1.3 Systematic uncertainties
Systematic uncertainties are discussed below, and listed in Table 1.

Subtraction of the BG discussed above provides the systematic uncertainties
includes the statistical errors in the detection efficiencies for BG processes, as
listed in the Table. Sizable uncertainties are found only in K − π 0 ην decay from
π − π 0 ην τ and the qq continuum and amount to 3.3% and 6.0%, respectively.
The systematic uncertainties for PID, track finding, π 0 and η reconstruction,
and the π 0 -veto are also estimated. The modeling of the PID likelihood is
tested by studying inclusive D * − samples for K/π and two-photon γγ → ℓ + ℓ −
samples for leptons; the Uncertainty in the PID efficiency is 2-3%, 1% and
∼ 2.5% for K ± , π ± and (µ/e) ± , respectively. The uncertainty for finding a
track is 1.0 % for hadrons and 0.3% for leptons. The uncertainty in π 0 /η → γγ
reconstruction is 2.0%, obtained from a comparison of η → γγ and η → π 0 π 0 π 0
data samples. The π 0 -veto inefficiency in π − π 0 ην τ samples is evaluated by
comparing its effect on the data and MC samples when the tag-side lepton-
PID criterion is reversed from the ordinary selection.

The statistical errors on the MC simulation are 0.5%, 1.7% and 0.5% for
τ − → K − ην τ , K − π 0 ην τ and π − π 0 ην τ in the η → γγ case, respectively, and
1.3% for τ − → K − ην τ in the η → π + π − π 0 case. The branching fractions
used in the MC are cited from Ref. [17], where B(η → π + π − π 0 ) yields a
sizable uncertainty of 1.6%, while others are negligible. The uncertainty of the
σ(e + e − → τ + τ − ) cross section and the integrated luminosity are 0.3% and
1.4%, respectively.
All contributions are summed up in quadrature to obtain the total uncer-
tainties; they amount to 5.9%, 9.1% and 5.3% for B(τ − → K − ην τ ), B(τ − →
K − π 0 ην τ ) and B(τ − → π − π 0 ην τ ), respectively, in the η → γγ case, and 6.2%
for B(τ − → K − ην τ ) in the η → π + π − π 0 case.
Taking into account the systematic errors, we obtain the following branching
fractions:
B(τ − → K − ην τ )
= (1.57 ± 0.05 ± 0.09) × 10 −4 for η → γγ,
(4)
= (1.60 ± 0.15 ± 0.10) × 10 −4 for η → π + π − π 0 ,
(5)
B(τ − → K − π 0 ην τ )
= (4.6 ± 1.1 ± 0.4) × 10 −5 ,
(6)
B(τ − → π − π 0 ην τ )
= (1.35 ± 0.03 ± 0.07) × 10 −3 .
(7)
For K − ην τ , the two measurements are combined to obtain
B(τ − → K − ην τ )
= (1.58 ± 0.05 ± 0.09) × 10 −4 .
(8)
4.2 π − K 0
S ην τ decay
4.2.1 Signal candidates
For π − K 0
S ην τ , the signal yield N η is evaluated from a fit to the M γγ mass
distribution in the same way, as discussed in 4.1.1, but the parameters of the
CB function are fixed to those determined by the signal MC simulation. The
fit result is shown in Fig. 5 (a), yielding N η = 161 ± 18 events.
We examine τ − → K − K 0
S ην τ and π − π + π − ην τ decays in order to determine
their cross-feed contaminations, with selection criteria similar to those for
π − K 0
S ην τ . For K − K 0
S ην τ , the charged track on the signal side is required to

solid curve with the BG shown by the dashed curve.
be a kaon; N η = 5.6 ± 3.6 events is obtained from the fit (see Fig.5 (b)).
For τ − → π − π + π − ην τ , its M γγ mass distribution, as shown in Fig. 5 (c), is
formed from a sample in which the π + π − invariant mass lies outside the K 0
S
mass range while the other requirements for K 0
S daughters are the same; the
fit gives N η = 67.9 ± 17.0 events.
4.2.2 Background
The possible background to the signal comes from π − π 0 K 0
S ην τ and the qq
continuum. The former sample is selected, requiring an additional π 0 on the
signal side. No clear η peak is found in the M γγ distribution, as can be seen
in Fig. 5 (d): N η = 4.7 +6.0
−5.1 events is obtained with a detection efficiency of
ǫ = 0.08%. We therefore set an upper limit on the branching fraction B(τ − →
π − K 0
S π 0 ην τ ) < 2.5 × 10 −5 at the 90% CL. The BG from this mode in the

π − K 0
S ην τ sample is calculated to be 1.6 +2.0
−1.7 events.
The contamination of q q in π − K 0
S ην τ decay is 21.1 ±7.5 events, following from
MC simulation with a scale factor estimated from the q q enriched sample.
After subtracting the two above BG's from the yield N η for π − K 0
S ην τ decay,
we solve the simultaneous equations of Eq.(3) in order to take into account the
cross-feeds among the three modes. Now, the (super)subscripts i, j = 1, 2, 3 for
the equations correspond to 1 = π − K 0
S ην τ , 2 = K − K 0
S ην τ , 3 = π − π + π − ην τ .
The last category includes other peaking BG from generic τ decays, which are
estimated using samples in the K 0
S sidebands. The detection efficiencies are,
for instance, ǫ 1
1 = 0.32% and ǫ 2
2 = 0.23%. The resulting branching fractions
are B(τ − → π − K 0
S ην τ ) = (4.38 ± 0.75) × 10 −5 and B(τ − → K − K 0
S ην τ ) =
(1.9 ± 2.0) × 10 −6 , respectively.
4.2.3 Systematic uncertainties
Systematic errors for B(τ − → π − K 0
S ην τ ) include the following sources. Un-
certainty in the signal CB function used to fit the M γγ spectrum is examined
by varying M η and σ Mη within their errors: the fitted yield N η varies by 0.7%.
The dominant BG comes from the q q continuum: its uncertainty is evaluated
to be 6.2%, while that of the others is negligible. The uncertainties in the
luminosity evaluation and σ(e + e − → τ + τ − ) are 0.3% and 1.4%, respectively.
The value of B(K 0
S → π + π − ) used in MC has a 0.4% error [17]. The uncer-
tainty in the CB function yields a 0.5% contribution. The total systematic
uncertainty is consequently calculated to be 7.9%, by adding all of the above
errors in quadrature.
As a result, we obtain the following branching fractions:
B(τ − → π − K 0
S ην τ )
= (4.4 ± 0.7 ± 0.3) × 10 −5 ,
(9)
and
B(τ − → K − K 0
S ην τ ) < 4.5 × 10 −6 ,
(10)
at the 90% CL.
4.3 τ − → K * − ην τ decay
The (Kπ) − invariant mass spectra in both τ − → K − π 0 ην τ and τ − → π − K 0
S ην τ
decays are analyzed to determine the K * (892) − content in the final state.

Fig. 6. (a) K − π 0 invariant mass distribution for K − π 0 ην τ events and (b) the π − K 0
S
invariant mass distribution for π − K 0
S ην τ events. Data are fitted with a convoluted
Breit-Wigner function, and the best fit is indicated by the solid curve, while the BG
component is shown by the dashed curve. The fits give N K * − ηντ = 122 ± 17 events
(a) and N K * − ηντ = 123 ± 14 (b), respectively.
4.3.1 τ − → K − π 0 ην τ samples
To select τ − → K − π 0 ην τ , the η signal is identified with the criterion 0.50 GeV/c 2 <
M γγ < 0.58 GeV/c 2 , and then the K − π 0 invariant mass M K − π 0 distribution is
analyzed (see Fig. 6 (a)). The contribution of the combinatorial BG under the η
peak is evaluated from the sidebands with 0.43 GeV/c 2 < M γγ < 0.48 GeV/c 2
and 0.60 GeV/c 2 < M γγ < 0.65 GeV/c 2 . The dashed curve in Fig. 6 (a) indi-
cates the BG component estimated from the above samples and from MC that
includes a τ decay with an η. A MC study indicates that the enhancement
in the higher M K − π 0 mass region mostly arises from π − π 0 ην τ events through
misidentification of π − → K − , while the dominant BG, mostly populating the
lower mass region, is composed of contributions from generic τ decays. A clear
K * (892) − signal over BG can be seen in the spectrum shown in Fig. 6 (a).
The observed M K − π 0 spectrum is fitted with a K * Breit-Wigner (BW) function
plus a BG component, where the former is convoluted with a response function

with a mass resolution of σ M K − π 0 = 13.5 MeV/c 2 . The latter is fixed so as to
reproduce the M K − π 0 spectrum of the sidebands. The mass and width of the
BW function are fixed to those of the K * (892) − [17] in the fit. The best-fit
result is indicated by the solid curve in the figure, and gives N K * − ηντ = 122±17
events with a χ 2 /d.o.f = 27.4/27.
We examine the non-resonant K − π 0 contamination by adding an additional
term in the fit, assuming a phase-space distribution with a V − A weak in-
teraction for a hadronic final system. The fit gives N K * − ηντ = 104 ± 20 events
and N non−K * − = 42 ± 25 events with a χ 2 /d.o.f = 24.5/26. Since no significant
difference between the two fits is found within the errors, we here simply take
the intermediate state to be purely K * − ην τ and the difference is taken into
account as the systematic uncertainty for the fitting function. Even allowing
for interference between the K * − and non-resonant K − π 0 , the difference is
found to be negligible.
No significant K * (892) − BG contribution is found in generic τ decays, while
6.5 ± 2.3 events are estimated from the q q MC.
The detection efficiency is evaluated from MC as ǫ = 0.12%, including the
branching fractions for K * (892) − → K − π 0 and η → γγ decays.
The systematic uncertainties in the evaluation of B(K * (892) − ην τ ) are summa-
rized in Table 2. The dominant error arises from the uncertainty in the fitting
function discussed above. It amounts to 15%. Other sources of systematic un-
certainties are the same as those for K − π 0 ην τ decay. The total systematic
uncertainty is 16.2%.
Thus we obtain the branching fraction
B(τ − → K * (892) − ην τ ) K * − →K − π 0
= (1.13 ± 0.17 ± 0.18) × 10 −4 .
(11)
For the non-resonant K − π 0 ην τ decay, we set an upper limit on its branching
fraction
B(τ − → K − π 0 ην τ ) non−resonant < 3.5 × 10 −5
(12)
at the 90% CL, assuming a pure phase-space distribution for the final hadronic
system.
4.3.2 τ − → K 0
S π − ην τ samples
The M K 0
S π − distribution is shown in Fig. 6(b) and is similar to the M K − π 0
case. A clear K * (892) − signal can be seen over a small continuum BG.

Table 2
Summary of the systematic uncertainties in K * − ην τ analysis (%).

Assuming no non-resonant K 0
S π − contribution, the distribution is fitted with a
convoluted BW function plus a BG, composed of a third-order polynomial, ap-
plying the same method used for the K − π 0 ην τ sample. The yield of K * (892) −
is 123 ± 14 events. The K * − BG is estimated to be 14.5 ± 5.0 events from the
q q continuum, and is subtracted from the above yield.
We examine a possible non-resonant K 0
S π − contribution, whose mass spectrum
is calculated by MC, assuming a pure hadronic phase-space distribution with
a V − A weak interaction. Including the non-resonant component, the best fit
gives N K * − = 121 ± 16 events and N non−resonant = 3 ± 15 events. Therefore, we
give results assuming no non-resonant background.
The detection efficiency is evaluated by MC as ǫ = 0.10%, which includes the
relevant branching fractions: B(K * (892) − → π − K 0
S ), B(K 0
S → π + π − ), and
B(η → γγ).
The systematic uncertainties are summarized in Table 2. Their magnitudes are
similar to those in the K − π 0 ην τ case, except for the non-resonant contribution.
The total systematic uncertainty is 6.4%. Consequently, the branching fraction

Table 3
Comparison with previous results.

τ − → π − K 0
S ην τ 0.44 ± 0.07 ± 0.02 1.10 ± 0.35 ± 0.11 CLEO [8]
τ − → K * − ην τ
1.34 ± 0.12 ± 0.09 2.90 ± 0.80 ± 0.42 CLEO [8]
is
B(τ − → K * (892) − ην τ ) K * − →π − K 0
S
= (1.46 ± 0.16 ± 0.09) × 10 −4 .
(13)
Two measurements using K * (892) − → K − π 0 and K 0
S π − decays are in agree-
ment, in accordance with isospin symmetry. Therefore we combine the two
results and obtain
B(τ − → K * (892) − ην τ )
= (1.34 ± 0.12 ± 0.09) × 10 −4 .
(14)
5 Result
Using a high statistics 450 million τ -pair data sample from Belle, we have
obtained the following branching fractions for five different decay modes:
B(τ − → K − ην τ ) = (1.58 ± 0.05 ± 0.09) × 10 −4 ,
B(τ − → π − π 0 ην τ ) = (1.35 ± 0.03 ± 0.07) × 10 −3 ,
B(τ − → K − π 0 ην τ ) = (4.6 ± 1.1 ± 0.4) × 10 −5 ,
B(τ − → π − K 0
S ην τ ) = (4.4 ± 0.7 ± 0.3) × 10 −5 ,
B(τ − → K * (892) − ην τ ) = (1.34 ± 0.12 ± 0.09) × 10 −4 ,
where the first and second errors are statistical and systematic, respectively.
We also set the upper limits on the following decay modes at the 90% CL:
B(τ − → K − K 0
S ην τ ) < 4.5 × 10 −6 ,

B(τ − → π − K 0
S π 0 ην τ ) < 2.5 × 10 −5 ,
B(τ − → K − ηην τ ) < 3.0 × 10 −6 ,
B(τ − → π − ηην τ ) < 7.4 × 10 −6 ,
B(τ − → K − π 0 ην τ ) non−resonant < 3.5 × 10 −5 .
In Table 3, our results are compared to those previously obtained by the
CLEO [6,7,8] and ALEPH [9] collaborations. It is clearly seen that the preci-
sion of the measured values has been considerably improved.
It is also noteworthy that the central values of our branching fractions are
in all modes lower than those of the other experiments [6,7,8,9]. This fact
can be mostly attributed to the underestimation of the BG contamination in
previous low statistics measurements. For instance, the q q BG estimation in
the previous analyses relied on the MC. However, this analysis evaluates the
BG rate using a q q enriched data sample. Furthermore, Ref. [7] ignored the
K − π 0 ην τ BG contribution, since they estimated it as ∼ 0.1% BG, based on a
theoretical calculation that predicted its branching fraction to be 8.8 × 10 −6
[3]. However, its rate is about 1% of the signal in our measurement, and its
branching fraction is about five times as large. Our high statistics allows us to
reliably and precisely scrutinize various BG contributions, while the previous
measurements, which had low statistics, did not have sufficient sensitivity to
notice, or correctly judge, the BG contamination.
Our results are compared with different theoretical calculations in Table 4. The
branching fraction for τ − → π − π 0 ην τ decay can be predicted by the isospin
symmetry (CVC) using the experimental results on e + e − → π + π − η [5,22].
Our branching fraction agrees with the predictions, B(τ − → π − π 0 ην τ ) =
(1.3 ± 0.2) × 10 −3 [5] and 1.5 × 10 −3 [22].
Pich [3], Braaten [23], Li [4] and Aubrecht [24] calculated the branching frac-
tions of various τ decays involving η meson(s), based on chiral perturbation
theory, as listed in Table 4. Their results are in fair agreement with our mea-
surements, particularly taking into account possible uncertainties in theoreti-
cal predictions. Further detailed studies of the physical dynamics in τ decays
with η mesons are required.
It should be mentioned that the TAUOLA MC program [14] qualitatively
reproduces our hadronic mass distributions in τ − → π − π 0 ην, τ − → K − ην
and τ − → K * (892) − ην decays, as shown in Fig. 7. Further analysis of the
spectra including various phenomenological models is in progress.

suppressed and negligible in our sample.
text.div:
We thank the KEKB group for the excellent operation of the accelerator, the
KEK cryogenics group for the efficient operation of the solenoid, and the KEK
computer group and the National Institute of Informatics for valuable com-
puting and SINET3 network support as well as Tau lepton physics research
center of Nagoya University. We acknowledge support from the Ministry of
Education, Culture, Sports, Science, and Technology of Japan and the Japan
Society for the Promotion of Science; the Australian Research Council and the
Australian Department of Education, Science and Training; the National Nat-
ural Science Foundation of China under contract No. 10575109 and 10775142;
the Department of Science and Technology of India; the BK21 program of the
Ministry of Education of Korea, the CHEP src program and Basic Research
program (grant No. R01-2008-000-10477-0) of the Korea Science and Engi-
neering Foundation; the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research; the
Ministry of Education and Science of the Russian Federation and the Russian
Federal Agency for Atomic Energy; the Slovenian Research Agency; the Swiss
National Science Foundation; the National Science Council and the Ministry
of Education of Taiwan; and the U.S. Department of Energy. This work is
supported by a Grant-in-Aid for Science Research on Priority Area (New De-

velopment of Flavor Physics) from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports,
Science and Technology of Japan and Creative Scientific Research (Evolution
of Tau-lepton Physics) from the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.
